error.signature: fatal: unable to access 'https://github.com/user/repo.git/': Could not resolve host: github.com
error.regex: (?i)fatal: unable to access.*https.*(?:could not resolve|SSL|Connection refused|timed out)

verdict.summary: Git cannot reach the remote HTTPS endpoint. Common causes include DNS resolution failures, proxy misconfiguration, SSL certificate issues, or corporate firewall blocking.

dead_ends.action: Disabling SSL verification globally with git config --global http.sslVerify false
dead_ends.why_fails: This opens the connection to man-in-the-middle attacks and does not fix DNS or connectivity issues. It only helps with certificate verification failures.

dead_ends.action: Switching to SSH without having SSH keys configured
dead_ends.why_fails: SSH requires key pairs to be generated, added to the agent, and registered with the remote host; switching without setup leads to permission-denied-publickey

workarounds.action: Diagnose and fix the network issue (DNS, proxy, firewall)
workarounds.how: Test connectivity with curl -v https://github.com. Check proxy settings with git config --global --get http.proxy. If behind a corporate proxy, set git config --global http.proxy http://proxy:port.

workarounds.action: Update SSL certificates if the error is SSL-related
workarounds.how: Run update-ca-certificates (Debian/Ubuntu) or point git to the correct CA bundle: git config --global http.sslCAInfo /path/to/ca-bundle.crt

leads_to.condition: when HTTPS access is restored but stored credentials have expired
when HTTPS issues also affect LFS object downloads

preceded_by.condition: when a remote was added with an incorrect HTTPS URL

frequently_confused_with.distinction: unable-to-access-https is an HTTPS connectivity problem; permission-denied-publickey is an SSH authentication problem
